div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.

div.head: New Mills For Egyptian Yarn
div.p: Some months ago Mr. William TattenU, of Manchester, prepared a list showing the namber of new Bpinning mills erected in iRnossfaire -ino* the commencement of the present ootton t>oom. This he has now brooght up to date, and the revised list reveals a farther striking ndfx to the great prosperity .of the staple in.toHtrv of the CoaDty Palatine. Wo gather that dwing the past eight months e'even new mills containing 940,356 spindles using Egyp- '*n ootton have rot to work, throe frith 280,000 spindles have partly oommenoed, and 19, to hold 1,845,000 spindles, are in ooarse of •rection. Three mills spinning American yarn, with a total of 240,0 0 spindles, have commenced running daring this period, and 35 mills t > contain 2,^48 000 spindles which will use American ootton, are being ereoted.

Comparing this list with a previous list of Mr. TattersaU's it appears that in three months the new mills to spin Egyptian ootton have increased from 80 to 33 and from 2,755,0C0 spindles to 8,065,356 spindles, while the mills to spio American ootton hare increased from 27 to 88 and from 9,300,000 spindhs to 8,088,000 spii'dlee. This is, L the cireamstanors, a remarkable in create, and it is not surprising that -spinners shoo!' h*ve some anxiety about the effeot of the cdming oompet tinn. It is evident from Mr. Tatterdall's list that a comparatively small □amber of the mills to spin American yarns have got to work, and yet onrrent report on the Manchester Exchange indicates tLat the American counts are at* present far lees remunerative than Egyptian oonnt*. It has hoen frequently asserted thit comparatively low piio«8 have been taken baoanse of the mar of this new competition, which might depress prices even farther. What will happen, one wonders, when the mills are all at work and where will Operatives be found to work them l Po* ibly some sceptical'psrions may hint that they will not all get to work, and the oarioas ciroamstanoes of the'flotation of^ome of them' has already been commented upon pretty freely. When the namber of projected new spindles exceeded 4,000 000 it wf-s said that the $n sines* was being overdose, hot »>ow the Bomber i* estimated at over $.000,0: 0. Oae point is worth notice, however, and that is that sooae oft he mills are not very fat in getting to work. According to Mr. Tattersall's figures not a single new spindle has • been turned on to American yarns for the last ttore months and though several mills that had ' partiv commenced" to sp'n Egyptian are now fally at work, no new one has started in this ssoUov. At present the spinning industry is in a flourishing omdition, and the market has assimilated the increased production of yarn Very well. We can on'y hope that a continued expansion of trade will show'any apprehensions to have been baseless.

div.head: Sudan Irrigation. The Bor-SObat Cut. AN AMPLE FALL DISCOVERED.
div.p: A discovery of the greatest importance for the fnture of the Sodan, and in faot of the Nile Valley generally, has just been made by the Sadan Irrigation 8ervice. For some time past a preliminary survey of the country to bp traversed by the proposed new channel between Bor and the Sobat has been made, and the remit is that it has been proved that there is an ample fall between these two points. The enormous importance of this factor it wonld be difficult to over-estimate, for it shows that it will eventually be possible to satisfactorily solve the problem of preventing the present wastage of the Upper Nile discharge in smn- mer, whereby the entire volume of 600 to 700 metres cube per seoond, which annually passes Lado daring the dry season, will be oonveyed to the White Nile with comparatively little loss. In other words, 50 per cent, should be added to the discharge of the river at Khartoum.

The originator of the magnificent idea of excavating an entirely new chancel for the summer water ot the Upper Nile, in an alignment running nearly dne north and sonth from Bor to the Sobat junotion on the White Nile, is Mr. J. 8 Beresford, late Inspeotor-General of Irrigation in India, who advocated the scheme in a conversation with Sir William Garetin, as is stated by the latter in the introduction to his moDnmental report on the basin of the Upper Nile. The distance from Bor to the Sobat by the new channel is 840 kilometres, bat from Bor to the Sobat via the Bahr el- Gebel and Lake No. is 710 kilometres and via the Bahr el-Zaraf is 650 kilometres.The question arose whether, with snch a redaction in the distance traversed by the water, the inorease in slope in the new channel wool! not be so ereat as, to render navigation impossible. But the survey has disproved these hypothetical difficulties and has shown that Mr. Beresford's scheme is qnite feasable.

Everything depended on this question of the levels for if there had been a great difference in the levels the scheme wonld have been rendered impossible except by the construction of a series of locks and regulators, which, in su^h a remote region, wonld have been almost impossible. As Sir William Garstin said in his report: "The first and the most argent necessity is a survey and a line of level across oonntry from the Sobat jnnotion to the point where the high bank abnts npon the Nile at Bor. Until this work has been completed it is useless to go into any farther detail, all that can be said is that the sohenfe npon paper looks a feasible one, and that should it prove to be so the advantages that wonld result from its exeontion are so great that it is worth a very considerable sacrifice of money and labonr to seoare each a great and lasting benefit to Egypt and the Northern Sudan."

As soon therefore as the Egyptian Government deoided to establish a permanent legation Service in the Sudan the atndy of Mr. Berfsford'e projeot took preoedenoe over all >tMlrs in that region. The preliminary snrvey is now just completed, with the result that the fall has been fonnd to be ample. Should the levelled survey have proved the scheme to be impossible then the question would have arisen of selecting either the Bahr el-Gebel or the Bahr el-Zaraf for improvements, bat neither ot these alternatives wonld be snch an effeotnal remedy as the new channel, for the immense advantages to be realised by leaving the great swamps of the White Nile altogether to one side and conveying water to the north in a wellconstrncted and folly- controlled channel are so evident that they oan be understood by all. 8noh a work as the excavation of this channel oonld only, owing to he impossibility of obtaining labonr, be exeont- ed by machinery. Powerfnl excavators wonld be indispensable, and workmight be commenced at either end and be carried on simnltaneonsly. It oonld probably be completed wi hin a shorter period cf time than that requisite for the remodelling of ether the Bahr-el-Ziraf or the Bahr- el-Ghszd. The Government will probably consider that the beet way of executing the work will be by giving it to eome large contracting firm. The opening ot the new line from the Nile to the Red 8ea will considerably facilitate the great undertaking by reducing the prohibitive price of coal, for without oheap ooal the work would, even if praotioable, have been delayed interminably.

The work may not be undertaken for some years to oome, but it is a great step forward to have discovered that the levels show that • he soheme is feasible, and Mr. Beresford is to be heartily oongratnlated on having originated the great projeot of revolutionising the most oelebrated waterway in the world by diverting it into a new channel. As soon as this ovannel for the summer water has been satisfactorily completed, the schemes for regulating on the Viotoria and Albert Lakes should be pnt in hand in order that a corstant discharge oi 1,000 metres onbe per second should be poored into the White Nile daring the season of lowest supply.

Mr. C. E. W. Dnpnis. Inspector General of 8ndan Irrigation, has just left Cairo for the Sndsn on his vey to the sonth to inspeot the important snrvey operations row going on in the Upper Nile regions.
Mr. Tottenham, Inspector of the same service, is now surveying the Babr-ol-Znraf in connection with future schemes for improving the channel of the river.

div.head: H. M. S. DONEGAL ASHORE. ASSISTANCE ASKED FROM SUEZ
div.p: Suez, Friday.

The British orniser Donegal sailed hence yesterday forenoon. To-day the Datch steamer Malang reports her ashore on Tor bank and has brought a message from her to the oaptain of the port urgently asking for tugs and lighters.
Suez, Saturday.
H.M.S. Donegal was refloated yesterday. All is reported to be well on board. Very little damage has been done to the vessel.

H.M.S. Donegal is a twin-screw armoured orniser of 9,800 tons and an indicated horse power of 22,0 0 N.D. She forms part of the First Cruiser Squadron and is on her way ont to the China station to relieve the Andromeda. The vessel is in command of Captain W. J. Grogan.

div.head: THE SCHOOL STRIKE
div.p: The Law School students held a meeting in the Verdi Theatre at 9 p.m. on Thursday, when a letter from Mr. Arohibald was read advising the resumption of work on Saturday. As the letter oontaioed no mention of the fonr pupils whose expulsion preoipitated the strike, the majority of the strikers olamonred for a oontinnanoe of the strike. The committee, which recommended cbnoiliatory taotios, was hooted and finally sneonmbed to an almost unanimous vote of oensnre and a new committee was appointed. .
The fonr pupils already mentioned interviewed Mr. Arohibald yesterday evening, with' what result was not known to onr correspondent at the time ot writing.

The headmaster of Rv?-el-Tin 8chool declares that his pnpils sent no telegram to the Ministry of Pablio Instruction to. the effect that they wonld go on strike if the grievances of their fellow* at Cairo were not remedied.
Oar Cairo Correspondent telephones : -

The great majority of the students of the Law Sohool attended the olasses this morning, only a very few refusing to retnrn to work. The majority, despite the entreaties of Mnstapha Pacha Kamel and several Cairo lawyers,thought better of their determination at the eleventh hoar and agreed to retnrn to work and await the Government ecqniry as to their grievanoes, which will be made in about two months' time, should the students pass a satisfactory period of probation.

The students of ths Agricultural College, who went on strike after being warned by the authorities of the oonseqnenoes that wonld follow their action, bhve been dismissed. We hear the college will dose till October next.

div.head: SUDAN ANTIQUITIES,
div.p: Mr. P. D. Scott Moocrieff of the British .Moseam, has been emp'oyed on arcbwologioal work by the 8adan Government. He has sncoessfally removed the north wall of the shrine of one of the Candaoe queers fonnd nearly two years ago by Dr. Wallis Bndge and 51 r. Crowfoot, Direo'or of Education, on the island of Merce, and has seen it safely erected in the Museum at Khattonm, now in a forward state, the companion wall on the southern Bide having been presented by the Sirdar to the British Museum. He has also finished the exoavation if the temple of Thot- mes III. at Wady Haifa, began by Mr. Holled- Smith and Dr. Bodge so long ago as 1866, resumed by Mr. Hayes-Sadler inj!892, ard continued by Dr. Bodge and Mr. Crowfoot in 1902, and has bnilt a mod wall all roand it to keep oat the sand—and tourists. At Senneh, sonth oi Wady Halftt, he discovered some interesting stelas and a fine statne of tha Middle Empire, which have yet to be investigated.

div.head: "INVESTMENTS"
div.p: "Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employement of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the Specially contributed Articles are "stock markets and how to profit by them;" "theory if Successful Speculation," "how to start an Account"; "the advantages of 'Call Options"; "Contaigoing Mining and Industrial Securities;" "How to Invest in Mines"; American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Invest,ent Securities by Instalments"; "General Principles for Investors"; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Priniples for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market operators' "Stck Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

div.head: Prospectus
div.p: La Societe Anonyme The Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company a ete foundee le 26 Novembre 1904 au Capital de 16,000 actions de L.E. 10 nominal entierement liberees.

Aux termes de ses statuts elle a pour objet l'etude, la preparation et l'execution pour son compte ou pour compte de tiers ou en participation de toutes operations en terrains et immeubles urbains on ruraux, de construction de canaux reservoirs, digues, drains, chemins de fer, tramaways, d'enterprises d'irrigation et generalement de tons travaux d'ame lioration ainsi que de toutes entreprises industrielles se rattachant a l'agriculture.

Despuis la fondation de la Societe, les affaires out immediatement pris un developpement tel que mon seulement le capital original a ete juge insuffisant, amis que meme l'augmentation de capital de L.E. 40,000 prevue par les statuts n'aurait pas permis d'etendre suffisamment les affaires de la Societe

Une assemblee generale extraordinaire des actionaires tenue au Caire le 15 Decemebre 1905 approuve a i'unanimite la proposition du COsneil de porter le capital a 400,000 par I'emission de 24,000 Actions Nouvelles du meme type que les actions anciennes et participant aux benefices sociaux a partir du 1 Janvier 1906.

Gette augmentaiton de capital a ete prise ferme par un groupe de financiers belges dirige par la Banque de Reports de Fonds Publics et de Depots a Anvers, et la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commmerce au Caire.
Sur ces 24,000 actions nouvelles, il en a ete souscrit 13,000 par les anciens actionnaires en vertu d'un droit de preference qui leur a ete reserve.
La solde sout 11,000 actions fait l'objet de la presente emission et est offert au public au prix de L.E. 12 PAR action.

La situation de la Societe telle qu'elle a ete exposes a l'Asemmblee generale ordinaire tenue le 20 Janvier dernier est des plus sati-faissantes. Les beneficies realises dans le coutant du premier exercice ont permis la distribution d'un dividende de 8 1/2% aux actions de capital et P.T. 35 aux parts de dividene.

L'exercice en cours se presente des mainemant sous un aspect des plus favorables. Un lot de terrain acquis I'an dernier vient d;ere realise avec un benefice d'environ LE 23,000 et des offices formesont ete faites a la Societe pour divers autres terrains a des prix qui laisseraien un benefice immediat de plus de L.E. 40,000.
Certaines affaires en participation ont acquis une telle plus value que leur realisation immediate assurerait un benefice considerable.

Ces quelques considerations suffront amplement pour demontrer que des maintenant la Societe a non seulement trouve un emploi remunerateur pour son nonveau capital, mais que I'on peut esperer wue les benefices du prevent exercice suffront largement pour distribuer sur l'ensemble du capital de L.E. 400,000 des dividndes au moins a equivalente a ceux de l'an dernier.

div.head: Injured By An Accident
div.p: Mr. W. J. Moore, 11, Pakefield-street, Pake field, Lowestoft, England, is well known and repsected. Although only 25 years of age, he has been connected with religious work for many years, and on most Sundays during the past 6 1/2 year he has ably occupied some village pulpit.

Some months back Mr. Moore wrote us a grateful lefter, telling of the good Dean'Back ache Kidney Pills had done him, and inviting us to send our representiave to get full particulars. This we have now done, and our readers will see that the case teems with interest:--

"It was when the electric tramway was being laid in Lowestoft," Mr, Moore began, "and I was at the wharf getting a load of cement. when suddenly and without warning, several tons of cement sliped, and before I knew what had happened, a bag struck me a glancing blw on the back. It was he worst pain Ive ever known, just as though my back was broken in two. They took me to the hospital, where for 27 weeks I lay hovering between life and death. The doctor said my kidneys were bruised and at length he gave up my case as hopeless, and at length he gav up my case as hopeless, and I was taken home.

Not one of my friends thought I could live. The pains I suffered in my back and hips were just as though you took out your pocket-knife and kept sticking the blade into me. I used to get dizzy and exhausted with the pains, and I suffered agonies from rheumatism as well as gravel and urinary trouble. I plastered my back until it was green, but so no relief could I suffered agonies from rheumatism, as well as gravel and urinary trouble. I plastered my back until it was green, but no relief could I get, and at last I because so weak with the constant suffering that I couldn't keep down a morsel of food. A watery willing came about my eyes, and for a fornight I couldn't see.

I told you in my letter." Mr. Moore went on, "how Doan's Backache Kidney Pills did me good from the start, and how they have. thank Providence, cured me, and I'm glad to have the opportunity of endorsing my letter with my old self again, and I'm as well to day as ever i was; there's no pain or urinary trouble at all. I'm so well, in fact, that for soem time I've been regularly following my new occupation as Insurane Agent, and "the grateful man went on, "I cycle over 100 miles every week, and generally walk frm 10 to 12 miles on a Sunday in connection with my preaching. That will show you what a sound and lasting oure mine is.

I have recommended Doan's Pills to several people, Mr. Moore concluded, "but my cure is the best recommendation that could be, for everyone round here knows how I suffered, and how splendidly Doan's Backache Kidney Pills have cured me."

div.head: Just Out. Reissue with Orgraphical Map of the Nile Valley. Our Sudan
div.p: By John Ward, F.S.A Assisted by Sir Reginald Wingate and his Officers, Sir William Qarstin, Lt.--Col. Count CLERIOMEN, AND and others.
Dedicated by request to Lord Kitchener of Khartoum. Crown 4to 400 pp. 720 illustrations. PRICE 21s net:
Letter from Sir Rudolf von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward, --Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me, I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. all of us who have done out little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands... I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that ahs come over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the peace and progress' is in fact a sequel to my Fire and Sword in the Sudan.
With the kindest regards, believe me,
Yours sincerely, Rudolf V. Slatin
John Murray, London.
To be had of all Booksellers in Egypt.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH aamp; ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;

2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
